challenges: Distinguishing between management-plane RBAC roles and data-plane Key Vault permissions
Navigating deprecated flags (enable_rbac_authorization) versus new flags (rbac_authorization_enabled) in the azurerm provider
Ensuring the correct service principal object ID (not app registration ID) was used for role assignments in CI
Interpreting Azureâ€™s 403 error messages to isolate missing data-plane permissions
learnings: Key Vault data-plane access requires specific secrets roles (e.g. Key Vault Secrets Officer), not just generic RBAC roles like User Access Administrator
RBAC mode for Key Vault must be explicitly enabled to make role assignments effective for secrets access
Using the service principal object ID consistently across Terraform and CI avoids subtle RBAC mismatches
A green Terraform apply from CI is the best confirmation that identity, RBAC, and remote state are correctly wired together
dailyLogs.notes: Today focused on fixing Key Vault access for Terraform running in GitHub Actions. By enabling RBAC mode on the vault, assigning a data-plane role to the CI service principal, and wiring the correct object ID into Terraform variables, the dev environment apply now completes successfully with secrets managed in Key Vault. This solidifies the RBAC and CI foundation for rolling the same pattern into test and prod.
